name: Salsify Kafka
description: A Ruby library for producing and consuming messages from Kafka. Consists of two major components: an actor framework for easily consuming messages with simplified concurrency control, and an event publisher for publishing events to Kafka. Both components require messages to be modeled as avromatic models.

name: Actor Framework
description: A component of salsify_kafka that allows clients to asynchronously process Kafka messages while ensuring that messages for a given actor are processed serially and in order. Handles organization-level worker fairness, retrying failed jobs with exponential back-off, long-running jobs that exceed Kafka session timeout, and metrics/monitoring. Uses Redis for message queuing and coordination.

name: Event Publisher
description: A component of salsify_kafka that provides methods for publishing messages to Kafka. Offers two modes: Transactional Event Publisher (provides a transactional Postgres gateway for atomically updating database state and enqueuing Kafka messages) and Direct Kafka Event Publishing (higher throughput option that bypasses the transactional gateway).

name: Message Router
description: A component of the salsify_kafka Actor Framework that pushes messages from Kafka into an actor's pending events table. Can be run via the rake task 'actors:route_messages'. Handles consumer group coordination and message distribution to appropriate actors.

name: Actor Worker
description: A component of the salsify_kafka Actor Framework that processes pending events for a given actor. Delegates to client-provided handlers for performing the real work of processing messages. Can be run via the rake task 'actors:work'.

name: Broken Actor
description: In the salsify_kafka Actor Framework, an actor that has failed to process an event after all retry attempts (default 8 attempts/80 minutes with exponential back-off). Broken actors will not process any events and require manual intervention to unbreak them using rake tasks.

name: Batched Actor
description: A variant of the salsify_kafka Actor class that processes a batch of messages for a single actor at a time instead of one message at a time. Handlers receive an array of events instead of a single event. Useful for bulk operations.

name: Cross-Actor Batching
description: A feature in the salsify_kafka Actor Framework that allows bulk operations across all actors in each worker's batch. Useful when you have a large number of actors or distinct event types and need to efficiently interact with external systems through load_batch and flush_batch hooks.

name: Non-Breaking Error
description: In the salsify_kafka Actor Framework, an error type that allows an actor to continue processing subsequent events after a failure instead of becoming broken. Useful for scenarios like external webhooks that may only succeed for certain payloads.

name: Avromatic
description: A related Salsify gem that salsify_kafka depends on. All messages published to Kafka must be modeled as avromatic models with a system_message_id for idempotent message processing.

name: System Message ID
description: A unique identifier required on all messages published to Kafka in salsify_kafka. Enables idempotent message processing by ensuring duplicate messages with the same ID are ignored within the retention window.

name: Metrics Reporter
description: A Salsify gem that salsify_kafka integrates with for emitting metrics and transactions to New Relic. Provides visibility into actor framework and event publisher operations.

name: Exception Reporter
description: A Salsify gem that salsify_kafka integrates with for reporting exceptions and errors that occur during Kafka message processing.

name: Salsify Avro
description: A Salsify library that provides the uniquely_identifiable_value Avro record type used for ensuring messages have a system_message_id for idempotent processing in salsify_kafka.

name: Rails Multitenant
description: A Salsify gem that the salsify_kafka Actor Framework integrates with to automatically set the current organization ID for handlers during message processing.
